ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained knowledge and insights about the ways that professors in the Department of Sociology have navigated their careers and scholarly development. Furthermore, I learned a few tips on how to think about professional development in the PhD process.
I got an insight into all the different approaches to academic life, got great advice from advanced scholars and learned about the faculty's research.
exposure to the breadth of sociological research in Yale's department. Exposure to a diversity of issue areas and methodologies
I learned a lot about the faculty, and their individual perspectives. I also learned a lot about how to hone my elevator pitch.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the course spends too much time having us informally chat with faculty versus coupling informal networking with intentional skill-building exercises led by faculty experts. However, I did appreciate having the chance to ask questions and learn from/about the experiences of faculty members in our department.
More focus on professional development skills

I enjoyed hearing from the faculty. However, I felt like at times they said too much about their interests and not enough about the professionalization piece. I definitely wanted to meet them and hear about their work, but it is called "professional seminar" for a reason - so I expected professionalization topics to be discussed.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This is a required course, so incoming students will have to take it each fall. However, I think that it would benefit the department to redesign the course to allow for informal networking and skill development in each session.
Necessary for all first year phD students
Yes, but I'd recommend they ask that there be specific talk about professionalization.
